elements.content: The present work reports facile synthesis, full characterization, and architectural diversity of seven Co­(II) coordination polymers, namely, [{Co­(H2MBP)2­(12-CDA)}·​CH3OH]∞ (1), [{Co­(H2MBP)­(12-CDA)­(H2O)}]∞ (2), [{Co0.5(H2MBP)­(14-CDA)0.5}·​(H2O)2.5]∞ (3), [{Co­(H2MBP)­(14-CDA)­(H2O)2}]∞ (4), [{Co­(H2MBP)­(13-ADA)0.5}]∞ (5), [{Co­(H2MBP)2­(135-CTA)­(H2O)}­(H2O)3.5]∞ (6), and [{Co2(μ2O)­(H2MBP)3­(1245-CHA)}­(H2O)12]∞ (7), derived from a 4,4′-methylene bispyrazole (H2MBP) ligand and various flexible dicarboxylate coligands. The type of alicyclic flexible carboxylate coligand used in the synthesis and its coordination to the metal center play a key role in controlling the dimensionality and topology of the frameworks. Topological analysis of the simplified nets reveals that 1 and 3 possess a 4-connected sql topology, 2 features a 3-connected uninodal hcb topology, 5 contains a 3D cds topology, and 7 possesses an unprecedented new 3D topology. Interestingly, a well-resolved 1D water chain is found within 3 and the presence of a heptanuclear water cluster assisted via a free carboxylate group is observed in 6. Chirality associated with 5 has been supported by solid-state CD spectra, and variable-temperature magnetic studies indicate that 7 exhibits canted magnetic coupling between the carboxylate bridged Co­(II) ions.

The type of alicyclic flexible carboxylate coligand used in the synthesis and its coordination to the metal center play a key role in controlling the dimensionality and topology of the frameworks. Interestingly, a well-resolved 1D water chain is found within 3 and the presence of a heptanuclear water cluster assisted via a free carboxylate group is observed in 6. Chirality associated with 5 has been supported by solid-state CD spectra, and variable-temperature magnetic studies indicate that 7 exhibits canted magnetic coupling between the carboxylate bridged Co(II) ions.

elements.content: Seven Co­(II) coordination polymers are constructed from an angular 4,4′-methylenebispyrazole (H2MBP) ligand with various flexible carboxylate colinkers. The resulting coordination polymer exhibits an unprecedented topology, water cluster, chirality, and spin-canted magnetic behavior.
elements.clean_text: Seven Co(II) coordination polymers are constructed from an angular 4,4'-methylenebispyrazole (H2MBP) ligand with various flexible carboxylate colinkers. The resulting coordination polymer exhibits an unprecedented topology, water cluster, chirality, and spin-canted magnetic behavior.

elements.content: In the past few decades, rational design and fabrication of coordination polymers (CPs) has flourished as an emerging area of research because of their promising application in guest molecule inclusion, gas and vapor storage, chemical sensing, magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, etc. One of the fundamental aspects of tuning the properties of CPs is to control their structural architectures, which is directly influenced by the judicious choice and self-assembly process involving metal ions and organic ligands. Presently, coordination driven self-assemblies of metal–ligand ensembles have occupied an important place in the domain of coordination as well as supramolecular chemistry due to their easy and spontaneous synthesis and novel applications. Several synthetic parameters such as temperature, pH of the medium, choice of metal precursors, and ligand-to-metal ratios are found to have a profound effect in controlling this self-assembly process. Moreover, literature reports have demonstrated that these self-assembled CPs often exhibit fascinating structure-dependent physical properties. One such very important property is chirality, which is intrinsically related to the topology of the framework obtained from the self-assembly process. In principle, chirality can be spontaneously induced into the network of CPs even if it is built from achiral building blocks and such chiral CPs are important in realizing various applications such as in heterogeneous catalysis, sensing, enantiomorph separation, etc. The self-assembly process also leads to the occurrence of different interesting structural topologies, which is another vital aspect of CPs since it significantly regulates their properties and applications. Generation of these architectural topologies often requires a system devoid of small organic or inorganic counterions, since counterions are often coordinated to the metal ion, resulting in a rather simpler framework. In this regard, a very promising approach is the use of mixed ligands such as N-donor heterocyclic ligands together with polycarboxylate organic colinkers in the same system. N-donor heterocyclic ligands, particularly pyrazole-based flexible or rigid linkers, are acclaimed for their high thermal stability and interesting structural topologies. Aromatic polycarboxylates are used extensively as organic colinkers since they often produce inherently rigid structures which have potential application in gas adsorption and storage. However, flexible cyclohexane carboxylate linkers are less explored as colinkers in designing CPs, although they are capable of inducing interesting structural features in the framework. The cyclohexane ring of such polycarboxylic acids can adopt various conformations, including boat, chair, twist boat, etc., depending on the coordination requirement of the metal ion, and thus can lead to unexpected and topologically unusual polymeric architectures. Literature study reveals that various conformational skeletons of cyclohexane polycarboxylic acids (CPAs) with a lack of rigidity in the structure lead to considerable complexity in the resulting frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past few decades, rational design and fabrication of coordination polymers (CPs) has flourished as an emerging area of research because of their promising application in guest molecule inclusion, gas and vapor storage, chemical sensing, magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, etc. One of the fundamental aspects of tuning the properties of CPs is to control their structural architectures, which is directly influenced by the judicious choice and self-assembly process involving metal ions and organic ligands. Presently, coordination driven self-assemblies of metal-ligand ensembles have occupied an important place in the domain of coordination as well as supramolecular chemistry due to their easy and spontaneous synthesis and novel applications. Several synthetic parameters such as temperature, pH of the medium, choice of metal precursors, and ligand-to-metal ratios are found to have a profound effect in controlling this self-assembly process. Moreover, literature reports have demonstrated that these self-assembled CPs often exhibit fascinating structure-dependent physical properties. One such very important property is chirality, which is intrinsically related to the topology of the framework obtained from the self-assembly process. In principle, chirality can be spontaneously induced into the network of CPs even if it is built from achiral building blocks and such chiral CPs are important in realizing various applications such as in heterogeneous catalysis, sensing, enantiomorph separation, etc. The self-assembly process also leads to the occurrence of different interesting structural topologies, which is another vital aspect of CPs since it significantly regulates their properties and applications. Generation of these architectural topologies often requires a system devoid of small organic or inorganic counterions, since counterions are often coordinated to the metal ion, resulting in a rather simpler framework. In this regard, a very promising approach is the use of mixed ligands such as N-donor heterocyclic ligands together with polycarboxylate organic colinkers in the same system. N-donor heterocyclic ligands, particularly pyrazole-based flexible or rigid linkers, are acclaimed for their high thermal stability and interesting structural topologies. Aromatic polycarboxylates are used extensively as organic colinkers since they often produce inherently rigid structures which have potential application in gas adsorption and storage. However, flexible cyclohexane carboxylate linkers are less explored as colinkers in designing CPs, although they are capable of inducing interesting structural features in the framework. The cyclohexane ring of such polycarboxylic acids can adopt various conformations, including boat, chair, twist boat, etc., depending on the coordination requirement of the metal ion, and thus can lead to unexpected and topologically unusual polymeric architectures. Literature study reveals that various conformational skeletons of cyclohexane polycarboxylic acids (CPAs) with a lack of rigidity in the structure lead to considerable complexity in the resulting frameworks.

elements.content: On the other hand, a 1H-pyrazole moiety has the ability to form intermolecular H-bonds as well as N–H···π interactions, resulting in higher dimensional supramolecular networks and imparting stability to the frameworks. The presence of flexible carboxylate coligands can also facilitate such supramolecular interactions by creating a suitable hydrophilic environment for encapsulation of guest solvents such as H2O. Notably, inclusion of H2O molecules inside porous CPs is unique because H2O plays an important role in various biological and chemical processes by forming different types of aggregates such as discrete H2O clusters, 1D water chain, 2D water layer, and 3D water structures. Among various water clusters, the presence of a 1D helical water channel inside porous CPs is of utmost importance since it resembles the helical water channel associated with the biological water transport phenomenon mediated by the membrane bound protein Aquaporin.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, a 1H-pyrazole moiety has the ability to form intermolecular H-bonds as well as N-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions, resulting in higher dimensional supramolecular networks and imparting stability to the frameworks. The presence of flexible carboxylate coligands can also facilitate such supramolecular interactions by creating a suitable hydrophilic environment for encapsulation of guest solvents such as H2O. Notably, inclusion of H2O molecules inside porous CPs is unique because H2O plays an important role in various biological and chemical processes by forming different types of aggregates such as discrete H2O clusters, 1D water chain, 2D water layer, and 3D water structures. Among various water clusters, the presence of a 1D helical water channel inside porous CPs is of utmost importance since it resembles the helical water channel associated with the biological water transport phenomenon mediated by the membrane bound protein Aquaporin.

elements.content: Inspired by these fundamentally important features of the self-assembled CPs obtained by a mixed ligand strategy, we extend our research endeavors to synthesize pyrazole-based functional CPs using H2MBP (H2MBP = 4,4′-methylenebispyrazole) and various cyclohexane polycarboxylic acids (CPA) as flexible organic linkers (Scheme ). So far, a wide range of CPs have been reported using H2MBP and various aromatic polycarboxylate ligands; however, cyclohexane polycarboxylates are yet to be exploited in such mixed ligand systems. Keeping this in mind, in this contribution, we report the syntheses and characterization of seven Co­(II) CPs using H2MBP and five cyclohexane polycarboxylates as coligands. The compounds are formulated as [{Co­(H2MBP)2­(12-CDA)}·​CH3OH]∞ (1), [{Co­(H2MBP)­(12-CDA)­(H2O)}]∞ (2), [{Co0.5(H2MBP)­(14-CDA)0.5}·​(H2O)2.5]∞ (3), [{Co­(H2MBP)­(14-CDA)­(H2O)2}]∞ (4), [{Co­(H2MBP)­(13-ADA)0.5}]∞ (5), [{Co­(H2MBP)2­(135-CTA)­(H2O)}­(H2O)3.5]∞ (6), and [{Co2(μ2O)­(H2MBP)3­(1245-CHA)}­(H2O)12]∞ (7). The structural insights of the resulting CPs along with the topological features have been thoroughly investigated by analyzing their single crystal structures. CP 7 displays an unprecedented 3D topology. In addition, we also observe 1D helical water chains in the crystal structure of 3. Interestingly, CP 5 crystallizes in a chiral space group, although none of the ligands are chiral. The presence of chirality in 5 is also supported by CD spectra. Furthermore, magnetic properties of 7 have been investigated in detail, which reveal dominant antiferromagnetic interactions at the high temperature region and spin-canting behavior at the lower temperature regime, arising mainly due to the canted orientation of the spins on the adjacent Co­(II) centers.

The compounds are formulated as [{Co(H2MBP)2(12-CDA)}⋅CH3OH]∞ (1), [{Co(H2MBP)(12-CDA)(H2O)}]∞ (2), [{Co0.5(H2MBP)(14-CDA)0.5}⋅(H2O)2.5]∞ (3), [{Co(H2MBP)(14-CDA)(H2O)2}]∞ (4), [{Co(H2MBP)(13-ADA)0.5}]∞ (5), [{Co(H2MBP)2(135-CTA)(H2O)}(H2O)3.5]∞ (6), and [{Co2(μ2O)(H2MBP)3(1245-CHA)}(H2O)12]∞ (7). elements.content: The ligand H2MBP is synthesized according to a reported procedure, and all the coordination polymers are synthesized via solvothermal methods taking the reactants in a 1:1:1 molar ratio and are found to be air-stable. The phase purity of the compounds is confirmed by PXRD analyses (Figures S1–S7 in the ), and thermal stability is measured by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figures S8–S14 in the ). Various flexible alicyclic cyclohexane polycarboxylic acids (CPAs), namely, 1,2-cyclohexane dicarboxylic acid (12-CDA), 1,3-adamentane dicarboxylic acid (13-ADA), 1,4-cyclohexane dicarboxylic acid (14-CDA), 1,3,5-cyclohexane tricarboxylic acid (135-CTA), and 1,2,4,5-cyclohexane tetracarboxylic acid (1245-CHA), are used as coligands. Conformational flexibility of the CPAs plays a decisive role in determining the overall structural patterns of the coordination networks. The insertion of flexible CPAs not only modifies the coordination environment of the metal ions by extending or blocking the polymerization but also dramatically affects the crystal packing through various weak interactions. Conformational mobility of CPAs coupled with strong supramolecular interactions (H-bonding, metal organic interactions, etc.) may also produce crystalline frameworks in which individual molecules may exist in energetically unfavorable or unusual conformation, as observed in compound 7. However, when there are more carboxylic groups on the cyclohexane ring, there will be more possible conformations; consequently, it is more difficult to control their orientation in the final coordination networks. In this present contribution, we have systematically investigated the coordination chemistry of five conformationally flexible CPAs. It has been also noticed that solvothermal reaction conditions also control the spatial orientation of carboxylate groups attached with CPAs. In the case of compounds 1–4, direct influence of solvothermal reaction temperature on the crystal structure of resulting CPs is observed.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The ligand H2MBP is synthesized according to a reported procedure, and all the coordination polymers are synthesized via solvothermal methods taking the reactants in a 1:1:1 molar ratio and are found to be air-stable. The phase purity of the compounds is confirmed by PXRD analyses (Figures S1-S7 in the ), and thermal stability is measured by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figures S8-S14 in the ). Various flexible alicyclic cyclohexane polycarboxylic acids (CPAs), namely, 1,2-cyclohexane dicarboxylic acid (12-CDA), 1,3-adamentane dicarboxylic acid (13-ADA), 1,4-cyclohexane dicarboxylic acid (14-CDA), 1,3,5-cyclohexane tricarboxylic acid (135-CTA), and 1,2,4,5-cyclohexane tetracarboxylic acid (1245-CHA), are used as coligands. Conformational flexibility of the CPAs plays a decisive role in determining the overall structural patterns of the coordination networks. The insertion of flexible CPAs not only modifies the coordination environment of the metal ions by extending or blocking the polymerization but also dramatically affects the crystal packing through various weak interactions. Conformational mobility of CPAs coupled with strong supramolecular interactions (H-bonding, metal organic interactions, etc.) may also produce crystalline frameworks in which individual molecules may exist in energetically unfavorable or unusual conformation, as observed in compound 7. However, when there are more carboxylic groups on the cyclohexane ring, there will be more possible conformations; consequently, it is more difficult to control their orientation in the final coordination networks. In this present contribution, we have systematically investigated the coordination chemistry of five conformationally flexible CPAs. It has been also noticed that solvothermal reaction conditions also control the spatial orientation of carboxylate groups attached with CPAs. In the case of compounds 1-4, direct influence of solvothermal reaction temperature on the crystal structure of resulting CPs is observed.

elements.content: Block-shaped crystals (pink) of 1 are isolated from solvothermal reaction of H2MBP with 12-CDA in the presence of Co­(OAc)2 at 70 °C temperature. When the same reaction is carried out at 120 °C, purple crystals of 2 are obtained. 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group with two crystallographically independent H2MBP molecules, one 12-CDA, one Co­(II) atom, and one noncoordinated methanol molecule in the asymmetric unit. The cyclohexane ring of the 12-CDA molecule in the crystal structure of compound 1 is found to exhibit some disordered effect, which presumably resulted due to the flipping of the chair conformation of cyclohexane. In the crystal structure, the Co­(II) atom attains an octahedral geometry (Figure a) where basal sites are occupied by four nitrogen atoms from two symmetry-independent H2MBP molecules and the other two axial sites are occupied by oxygen atoms from the carboxylate ligand (corresponding bond angles and lengths are summarized in Table S1 in the ). In the crystal structure, the N-donor ligand forms a 1D looped-chain topology by extended coordination with the adjacent Co­(II) metal centers and such 1D chains are further bridged by the dicarboxylate ligand, resulting in a 2D network (Figure b). Such 2D sheets are further packed in a parallel ABAB fashion, and the interstitial space is occupied by the lattice occluded MeOH molecules further sustained by H-bonding with the N–H of H2MBP and carboxylate O atoms (Table S2 in the ). Due to the (e,e) conformation of the 12-CDA molecule in the crystal structure, it typically acts as a V-shaped linker. Mutual interplay of the bent N-donor heterocyclic moiety and the V-shaped carboxylate linker coordinated to the adjacent metal center in an alternating fashion results in a helical network of both handednesses (Figure d), which is also reflected on its achiral space group (P21/n). For the sake of topological classification of the coordination networks, we have carried out topological analysis using TOPOS 4.0 software following the concept of simplifying underlying nets. Topological investigations reveal that it is a uninodal 4-connected sql (square lattice) (Figure c) net with point symbol {44.62}. The presence of helicity in sql type nets is rarely observed.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description

Crystal Structures of [{Co(H2MBP)2(12-CDA)}⋅(CH3OH)]∞ (1) and [{Co(H2MBP)(12-CDA)(H2O)}]∞ (2)

Block-shaped crystals (pink) of 1 are isolated from solvothermal reaction of H2MBP with 12-CDA in the presence of Co(OAc)2 at 70 °C temperature. When the same reaction is carried out at 120 °C, purple crystals of 2 are obtained. 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group with two crystallographically independent H2MBP molecules, one 12-CDA, one Co(II) atom, and one noncoordinated methanol molecule in the asymmetric unit. The cyclohexane ring of the 12-CDA molecule in the crystal structure of compound 1 is found to exhibit some disordered effect, which presumably resulted due to the flipping of the chair conformation of cyclohexane. In the crystal structure, the Co(II) atom attains an octahedral geometry (Figure a) where basal sites are occupied by four nitrogen atoms from two symmetry-independent H2MBP molecules and the other two axial sites are occupied by oxygen atoms from the carboxylate ligand (corresponding bond angles and lengths are summarized in Table S1 in the ). In the crystal structure, the N-donor ligand forms a 1D looped-chain topology by extended coordination with the adjacent Co(II) metal centers and such 1D chains are further bridged by the dicarboxylate ligand, resulting in a 2D network (Figure b). Such 2D sheets are further packed in a parallel ABAB fashion, and the interstitial space is occupied by the lattice occluded MeOH molecules further sustained by H-bonding with the N-H of H2MBP and carboxylate O atoms (Table S2 in the ). Due to the (e,e) conformation of the 12-CDA molecule in the crystal structure, it typically acts as a V-shaped linker. Mutual interplay of the bent N-donor heterocyclic moiety and the V-shaped carboxylate linker coordinated to the adjacent metal center in an alternating fashion results in a helical network of both handednesses (Figure d), which is also reflected on its achiral space group (P21/n). For the sake of topological classification of the coordination networks, we have carried out topological analysis using TOPOS 4.0 software following the concept of simplifying underlying nets. Topological investigations reveal that it is a uninodal 4-connected sql (square lattice) (Figure c) net with point symbol {44.62}. The presence of helicity in sql type nets is rarely observed.

elements.content: CP 2 belongs to monoclinic C2/c space group with one Co­(II) atom, one H2MBP molecule, one 12-CDA molecule, and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. Co­(II) adopts a distorted octahedral geometry with basal sites occupied by carboxylate oxygen atoms coming from two different 12-CDA molecules and one nitrogen atom from an H2MBP molecule; the axial sites are occupied by one water molecule and one nitrogen atom from an H2MBP molecule (Figure a; Table S3 in the ). Here, H2MBP links two adjacent metal centers, forming M2L2 type discrete loops. Such loops are further bridged by a 12-CDA linker, forming a 2D sheet structure, as depicted in Figure b. As observed in compound 1, the cyclohexane ring of the 12-CDA molecule in the crystal structure of compound 2 suffers from a similar kind of disorder effect. Unlike 1, the crystal structure of 2 lacks any helical character. Topological analysis of the crystal structure reveals it as a 3-coordinated uninodal hcb (honeycomb) net with point symbol {63}, where an M2L2 type loop motif has been utilized as a vertex of the net (Figure ). Each of the 2D hcb layers is further stacked in an ABCABC fashion through weak interaction between parallel layers that is further reinforced by H-bonding interactions (Table S4 in the ) involving carboxylate oxygen atoms and pyrazole N–H to form an overall 3D structure.

Here, H2MBP links two adjacent metal centers, forming M2L2 type discrete loops. Such loops are further bridged by a 12-CDA linker, forming a 2D sheet structure, as depicted in Figure b. As observed in compound 1, the cyclohexane ring of the 12-CDA molecule in the crystal structure of compound 2 suffers from a similar kind of disorder effect. Unlike 1, the crystal structure of 2 lacks any helical character. Topological analysis of the crystal structure reveals it as a 3-coordinated uninodal hcb (honeycomb) net with point symbol {63}, where an M2L2 type loop motif has been utilized as a vertex of the net (Figure ). Each of the 2D hcb layers is further stacked in an ABCABC fashion through weak interaction between parallel layers that is further reinforced by H-bonding interactions (Table S4 in the ) involving carboxylate oxygen atoms and pyrazole N-H to form an overall 3D structure.

elements.content: When a diverging 14-CDA ligand has been used as a coligand instead of 12-CDA, another two coordination polymers 3 and 4 are isolated once again at two different temperatures. Solvothermal reaction of H2MBP and Co­(OAc)2 in the presence of 14-CDA at 120 °C results in the formation of 3, whereas, when the same reaction is repeated at 70 °C, pink crystals of 4 are isolated. The asymmetric unit of 3 consists of one Co­(II) atom (situated on an inversion center), one H2MBP molecule, one 14-CDA molecule situated on a special position (inversion center) (Figure ), and three lattice occluded water molecules. A pair of carboxylate oxygen atoms coming from two adjacent 12-CDA coligands bind axially with the Co­(II) atom, whereas four N atoms coming from H2MBP molecules constitute the equatorial plane of the octahedron (bond angles and bond lengths are summarized in Table S5 in the ).

When a diverging 14-CDA ligand has been used as a coligand instead of 12-CDA, another two coordination polymers 3 and 4 are isolated once again at two different temperatures. Solvothermal reaction of H2MBP and Co(OAc)2 in the presence of 14-CDA at 120 °C results in the formation of 3, whereas, when the same reaction is repeated at 70 °C, pink crystals of 4 are isolated. The asymmetric unit of 3 consists of one Co(II) atom (situated on an inversion center), one H2MBP molecule, one 14-CDA molecule situated on a special position (inversion center) (Figure ), and three lattice occluded water molecules. A pair of carboxylate oxygen atoms coming from two adjacent 12-CDA coligands bind axially with the Co(II) atom, whereas four N atoms coming from H2MBP molecules constitute the equatorial plane of the octahedron (bond angles and bond lengths are summarized in Table S5 in the ).

elements.content: The auxiliary linker 14-CDA adopts a trans-e,e conformation in the crystal structure, which connects the 1D looped chain constituted by H2MBP molecules, resulting in a 2D coordination network with 4-connected sql topology (Figure a). Such 2D sheets are further packed in a parallel fashion, and 1D hydrogen bonded water clusters are located between the 2D layers sustained by various H-bonding interactions with the carboxylate oxygen atoms and pyrazole N atoms (Figure b). The geometrical parameters pertaining to the water chain are shown in the (Table S6). One of the lattice occluded solvent O3 is situated around a crystallographic inversion center with an occupancy of 0.5. The oxygen atoms associated with water chain are not coplanar and rather form an unprecedented wave pattern extending along the crystallographic a axis. The O···O distance in between the oxygen atoms in the water chain ranges from 2.74 to 2.95 Å, which is consistent with the O···O distance found in other 1D helical water channels stabilized in porous MOFs. Interaction of pyrazole N atoms and carboxylate O atoms with the lattice solvent molecules further strengthens the stabilization of the water chain. TGA of 3 (Figure S10 in the ) is performed to check the thermal stability of the CP and also that of the 1D water channels. The TG profile shows that the initial weight loss started at an onset temperature 30 °C with 15.10% weight loss, which corresponds to the loss of lattice occluded water molecules. DSC data (navy blue graph in Figure S10 in the ) show that the water loss process is endothermic in nature. The compound remains stable up to 200 °C and starts dissociating after that.

One of the lattice occluded solvent O3 is situated around a crystallographic inversion center with an occupancy of 0.5. The oxygen atoms associated with water chain are not coplanar and rather form an unprecedented wave pattern extending along the crystallographic a axis. The O⋅⋅⋅O distance in between the oxygen atoms in the water chain ranges from 2.74 to 2.95 Å, which is consistent with the O⋅⋅⋅O distance found in other 1D helical water channels stabilized in porous MOFs. Interaction of pyrazole N atoms and carboxylate O atoms with the lattice solvent molecules further strengthens the stabilization of the water chain. TGA of 3 (Figure S10 in the ) is performed to check the thermal stability of the CP and also that of the 1D water channels. The TG profile shows that the initial weight loss started at an onset temperature 30 °C with 15.10% weight loss, which corresponds to the loss of lattice occluded water molecules. DSC data (navy blue graph in Figure S10 in the ) show that the water loss process is endothermic in nature. The compound remains stable up to 200 °C and starts dissociating after that.

elements.content: Since we have utilized commercially available 14-CDA, which is found as a mixture of cis and trans isomers in a molar ratio of 3:2 as starting material, a new coordination polymer 4 is isolated with the cis conformer of 14-CDA. It has been well documented that mixing of isomers in the starting materials results in the formation of products with different conformations of 14-CDA depending upon the external conditions. The difference in the spatial orientation of the carboxyl group in two different isomers of 14-CDA brings subtle differences in the resulting structures. In the crystal structure of CP 4, the carboxylate ligand 14-CDA assumes a cis-a,e conformation which resembles an L-shaped bent linker. The asymmetric unit contains one H2MBP molecule, one 14-CDA ligand, one Co­(II) atom, and two coordinated water molecules. The central Co­(II) atom assumes an octahedral geometry, as depicted in Figure a, with equatorial coordination from two N atoms of symmetry related H2MBP ligands and two O atoms of 14-CDA molecules; the axial sites are occupied by water molecules (bond angles and bond lengths are summarized in Table S7 in the ). Unlike CP 3, here, the orientation of the 14-CDA molecule is such that it provides hydrophobic character to the framework and thus repels the polar solvent molecules. In the crystal structure, the N-donor heterocyclic ligand and the carboxylate linker mutually participate in forming the helical 1D framework. Such helical chains propagate in 2D via H-bonding interaction sustained by metal bound water molecules and further supported by carboxylate oxygen and pyrazole nitrogen atoms, as depicted in Figure b (Table S8 in the ).

elements.content: Interestingly, the compound exhibits chirality with a noncentrosymmetric space group P212121, although none of the starting materials are chiral. The circular dichroism (CD) spectra (Figure S18 in the ) of the compound confirm the chirality of the molecule. The chirality arises in this case presumably because of the helical type framework formed by mutual participation of H2MBP and the 12-CDA linker. The solid-state CD spectrum is recorded using a diffuse reluctance technique by taking a very small amount of crystalline sample in the KBr matrix. 5 exhibits a positive Cotton effect with a dichroic signal at 238 nm. Repeating the experiment with several batches of crystals shows a similar positive Cotton effect, which supports the formation of enantiomerically pure product.

elements.content: When 13-ADA is used in place of 14-CDA, and the synthesis conditions were changed into a mixed solution of DMF, MeOH, and H2O at 80 °C, CP 5 is obtained. From the X-ray crystal structure analysis, it is revealed that the asymmetric unit consists of a half Co­(II) atom situated on a glide plane, one H2MBP ligand and one-half of a 13-ADA molecule situated on a 2-fold axis. The central Co­(II) atom exhibits an octahedral geometry (Figure a) with four pyrazole N atoms at the basal positions, whereas the axial sites are occupied by carboxylate O atoms coming from 13-ADA molecules (bond angles and bond lengths and H-bonding parameters are provided in Tables S9 and S10 in the ).

elements.content: The fundamental building block of this 3D framework is a 1D looped chain topology in which metal centers are coordinated with an N-donor heterocyclic moiety. Such 1D looped chains oriented almost orthogonally are further bridged by a 13-ADA coligand, resulting in a 3D framework (Figure S19 in the ). A better insight of this intriguing framework can be achieved by employing a topological approach which reduces the complicated multidimensional nets into a rather simpler framework. Considering all Co­(II) as four connected nodes and connecting the nodes according to the connectivity defined by H2MBP and 13-ADA, the crystal structure can be simplified as a 3D cadmium sulfate (cds) topology (Figure b) with point symbol {65.8}.
elements.clean_text: The fundamental building block of this 3D framework is a 1D looped chain topology in which metal centers are coordinated with an N-donor heterocyclic moiety. Such 1D looped chains oriented almost orthogonally are further bridged by a 13-ADA coligand, resulting in a 3D framework (Figure S19 in the ). A better insight of this intriguing framework can be achieved by employing a topological approach which reduces the complicated multidimensional nets into a rather simpler framework. Considering all Co(II) as four connected nodes and connecting the nodes according to the connectivity defined by H2MBP and 13-ADA, the crystal structure can be simplified as a 3D cadmium sulfate (cds) topology (Figure b) with point symbol {65.8}.

elements.content: Structural investigation reveals that compound 6 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group. The asymmetric unit comprises one Co­(II) atom, two H2MBP molecules, one 135-CTA molecule, and four lattice occluded water molecules. One of the lattice occluded water molecules O13 is situated around an inversion center, and its occupancy becomes 0.5. The central Co­(II) atom attains an octahedral geometry with four N atoms coming from two different H2MBP molecules at the basal plane, whereas one of the axial sites is occupied by a free water molecule and the other site is ligated by one carboxylate oxygen atom of 135-CTA (Figure a) (bond angles and bond lengths are summarized in Table S11 in the ). The auxiliary ligand 135-CTA adopts its most stable cis-e,e,e conformation in the crystal structure. As observed in earlier cases, H2MBP forms a 1D looped chain topology by coordinating with adjacent metal centers (Figure b) in which 135-CTA utilizes only one carboxylate group to bind with the metal, keeping the other two carboxylates free. Such coordination of the coligand creates a suitable environment for solvent inclusion. Interestingly, a seven-membered water cluster H-bonded to the carboxylic moieties free from coordination has been identified within the crystal structure (Figure c). The O···O distance found in the water cluster ranges from 2.69 to 3.00 Å, and the O···O···O angles span from 76.26° to 81.59°, which deviates considerably from the value of 109.3° found in ice. In addition, not all the oxygen atoms present in the crystal structure exhibit four coordination. This reflects the strong influence of the host crystalline framework on the conformation exhibited by the water cluster. The water cluster fits itself inside the cavity of the framework by maximizing the interactions with the MOF (H-bonding parameters are summarized in Table S12 in the ). The TGA profile of 6 (Figure S13 in the ) also suggests considerably strong MOF–water cluster interaction. The initial weight loss starts at an onset temperature of 30 °C, after which the compound remains stable up to 320 °C. The overall framework is a 3D supramolecular architecture in which each of the 1D chains is further packed in two other directions by coordination through lattice bound water molecules further sustained by carboxylate oxygen atoms and pyrazole N–H atoms from H2MBP.

elements.content: 1245-CHA is a versatile organic linker that can exist in four possible conformational isomers, namely, I (e,a,a,e), II (e,a,e,e), III (e,a,e,a), and IV (e,e,e,e). As suggested by the free energy values, conformer II is the most stable and conformer I is the least stable form in both gas and solution phases. Coordination with the metal ion plays a vital role in controlling the orientation of the carboxylate group on the cyclohexane ring in such a sterically crowded system. In compound 7, under hydrothermal conditions, the ligand 1245-CHA remains in conformation I presumably because the energy disadvantage is compensated via metal coordination and several supramolecular interactions such as hydrogen bonding. Crystal structure analysis reveals that this compound crystallizes in the P21/n space group with three crystallographically independent H2MBP molecules, one 1245-CTA, two Co­(II) atoms, one μ2 bridging O atom, and two noncoordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit. Two crystallographically independent Co­(II) atoms acquire two completely different sets of environments in the crystal structure. The octahedral geometry of Co (1) is composed of four N atoms coming from two different H2MBP molecules and two O atoms from the 1245-CHA linker (Figure S20 in the ). Co (2) possesses a distorted octahedral coordination in which the square base is offered by one N atom from an H2MBP molecule, two carboxylate oxygen atoms, and one bridging O atom. Axial coordination comes from one N atom from a H2MBP molecule and one bridging O atom (respective bond lengths and bond distances are given in Table S13 in the ). Two Co2 centers are bridged by two carboxyl groups from 1245-CHA with a Co···Co distance of 3.10 Å, forming a system which resembles a paddle wheel. Versatile coordination of 1245-CHA produces a complicated 3D framework depicted in Figure a. Better insight into the complicated 3D architecture can be achieved from topological analysis. Since the structure contains polynuclear groups, a cluster method has been utilized, which revealed a 3 nodal net (Figure b) with stoichiometry (3-c)­2­(4-c)­(4-c)­2. The point symbol for the net is {105.12}­{3.102}­2­{32.103.11}­2.

elements.content: Structural comparison of the CPs 1–7 shows a stepwise increase in complexity of the resultant frameworks as either the flexibility or the substituents of the carboxylate colinkers are increased. Depending on the coordination requirement of the central metal ion, the H2MBP molecule adopts either cis or trans conformations (Scheme ). Various parameters associated with the conformational variation of the H2MBP molecule are listed in Table (Figure S21 in the ). There are some striking resemblance in the structural features of the seven CPs, although they give rise to various topological architectures.

Conformational Parameters of H<sub>2</sub>MBP Molecules in CPs (<bold>1</bold>–<bold>7</bold>)­<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t2fn1"></xref> structures θ (deg) φ (deg) d (Å) conformation 1 93.69 56.03 8.373 trans 2 97.96 –43.69 8.731 trans 3 100.03 –54.90 8.807 trans 4 107.50 3.61 9.237 cis 5 103.94 9.32 9.021 cis 6 94.77 –53.01 8.497 trans 7 98.56 –3.97 8.594 cis

Here, θ represents the angle between two coordinating nitrogen atoms of H2MBP, φ represents the dihedral angle between two pyrazole moieties of the H2MBP molecule, and d represents the metal–metal distance.

It has been observed that, in most of the CPs (except 2 and 4), the V-shaped H2MBP ligand connects the adjacent metal centers, forming a 1D looped chain topology. Another important feature of 1H-pyrazoles is their ability to restrict metal carboxylate cluster formation. Among two available nitrogens of 1H-pyrazoles, one coordinates to the metal, whereas the other NH remains free, which invariably forms hydrogen bonds with carboxylate oxygen atoms. Thus, carboxylate groups are forced to adopt monodentate coordination in the resulting CPs. This trend is observed for almost all the coordination polymers described in this study with a partial deviation for 7. In the case of 7, 1245-CHA is the auxiliary linker, which contains four carboxylate groups. Due to the steric bulk of this molecule, it orients itself in the resulting framework in such a way that one of the carboxylate groups participates in metal–carboxylate cluster formation while the other remains in monodented coordination. Furthermore, reaction temperatures, solvents, and ligand-to-metal ratios are found to have crucial influence on the ultimate structures.

Another important feature of 1H-pyrazoles is their ability to restrict metal carboxylate cluster formation. Among two available nitrogens of 1H-pyrazoles, one coordinates to the metal, whereas the other NH remains free, which invariably forms hydrogen bonds with carboxylate oxygen atoms. Thus, carboxylate groups are forced to adopt monodentate coordination in the resulting CPs. This trend is observed for almost all the coordination polymers described in this study with a partial deviation for 7. In the case of 7, 1245-CHA is the auxiliary linker, which contains four carboxylate groups. Due to the steric bulk of this molecule, it orients itself in the resulting framework in such a way that one of the carboxylate groups participates in metal-carboxylate cluster formation while the other remains in monodented coordination. Furthermore, reaction temperatures, solvents, and ligand-to-metal ratios are found to have crucial influence on the ultimate structures.

elements.content: Magnetic measurements are carried out on a well-powdered crystalline sample using a SQUID VSM Magnetometer (Quantum Design, USA). Temperature dependence of the molar magnetic susceptibility (χM) of complex 7 is measured in the temperature range of 2–300 K at 0.1 T and is shown as χM T vs T and χM vs T plots in Figure . At room temperature, a χM T value of 4.82 cm3 mol–1 K is observed, which is greater than the expected spin-only value of 3.75 cm3 mol–1 K for two high-spin octahedral Co­(II) ions with S = 3/2 and g = 2.0. Here, only the dinuclear unit is considered for magnetic data interpretation because, due to the appreciable distance (6.37–8.59 Å) between the dinuclear Co­(II) unit and the isolated Co­(II) centers, there is a lack of suitable magnetic exchange pathways between them. The higher χM T value at room temperature is due to unquenched orbital–moment as a consequence of spin–orbit coupling typical of the 4T1g ground state of the octahedral high-spin Co­(II) ion. As the temperature decreases from room temperature, χM T declines very slowly up to about 105 K, after which the value decreases rapidly until a value of 4.39 cm3 mol–1 K is reached at ∼25 K. This is followed by a sharp increment in χM T values at low temperatures to a value of 4.71 cm3 mol–1 K at 6 K. Below this temperature, again, an abrupt drop in the curve is noticed. The decline in the χM T value from 300 K is due to an antiferromagnetic (AFM) interaction between the neighboring Co­(II) centers. For an antiferromagnetic system, the exhibition of such a feature in the susceptibility curve at the lower temperature region can be ascribed to spin-canting behavior, which appears to arise from canted arrangements of spins on the adjacent Co­(II) centers. The spin-canting mechanism, which is known to originate through an antisymmetric interaction, requires the absence of an inversion center between the canted spins. Since, in compound 7, no inversion center is actually present, this structural feature might be responsible for the spin-canting behavior.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Property Studies

Magnetic measurements are carried out on a well-powdered crystalline sample using a SQUID VSM Magnetometer (Quantum Design, USA). Temperature dependence of the molar magnetic susceptibility (χM) of complex 7 is measured in the temperature range of 2-300 K at 0.1 T and is shown as χM T vs T and χM vs T plots in Figure . At room temperature, a χM T value of 4.82 cm3 mol-1 K is observed, which is greater than the expected spin-only value of 3.75 cm3 mol-1 K for two high-spin octahedral Co(II) ions with S = 3/2 and g = 2.0. Here, only the dinuclear unit is considered for magnetic data interpretation because, due to the appreciable distance (6.37-8.59 Å) between the dinuclear Co(II) unit and the isolated Co(II) centers, there is a lack of suitable magnetic exchange pathways between them. The higher χM T value at room temperature is due to unquenched orbital-moment as a consequence of spin-orbit coupling typical of the 4T1g ground state of the octahedral high-spin Co(II) ion. As the temperature decreases from room temperature, χM T declines very slowly up to about 105 K, after which the value decreases rapidly until a value of 4.39 cm3 mol-1 K is reached at ~25 K. This is followed by a sharp increment in χM T values at low temperatures to a value of 4.71 cm3 mol-1 K at 6 K. Below this temperature, again, an abrupt drop in the curve is noticed. The decline in the χM T value from 300 K is due to an antiferromagnetic (AFM) interaction between the neighboring Co(II) centers. For an antiferromagnetic system, the exhibition of such a feature in the susceptibility curve at the lower temperature region can be ascribed to spin-canting behavior, which appears to arise from canted arrangements of spins on the adjacent Co(II) centers. The spin-canting mechanism, which is known to originate through an antisymmetric interaction, requires the absence of an inversion center between the canted spins. Since, in compound 7, no inversion center is actually present, this structural feature might be responsible for the spin-canting behavior.

elements.content: The sudden drop in the χM T value at even lower temperatures (6–2 K) is attributed to a zero-field-splitting (ZFS) effect. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility (1/χM) is fitted according to the Curie–Weiss law, [χM T = C/(T – θ)], affording a Curie constant C = 4.84 cm3 mol–1 K and Weiss temperature θ = −1.08 K (Figure S15 in the ). The negative θ value can be attributed to both AFM exchange coupling and spin–orbit coupling effects, and therefore, the exchange parameters could not be estimated. The isothermal magnetization curve (M/NμB vs H curve, Figure S16a in the ) shows an almost saturated value of 3.62 NμB at 2 K and 5 T, which is less than the expected value of 6 NμB for two Co­(II) ions, also suggesting the spin-canting state at the low temperature range. Additionally, from the M/NμB vs H/T plot (Figure S16b in the ), it is observed that the isothermal magnetization curves do not superimpose, which indicates anisotropy, so the AC magnetization dynamics were also studied as a function of temperature and frequency, in zero and higher DC fields and 3.5 Oe AC field (Figure S17a–d, ). However, no ac signals were obtained, which is likely due to a small energy barrier or quantum tunneling of magnetization (QTM), and this rules out the possibility of single molecular magnetic (SMM) behavior of complex 7.

The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility (1/χM) is fitted according to the Curie-Weiss law, [χM T = C/(T - θ)], affording a Curie constant C = 4.84 cm3 mol-1 K and Weiss temperature θ = -1.08 K (Figure S15 in the ). The negative θ value can be attributed to both AFM exchange coupling and spin-orbit coupling effects, and therefore, the exchange parameters could not be estimated. The isothermal magnetization curve (M/NμB vs H curve, Figure S16a in the ) shows an almost saturated value of 3.62 NμB at 2 K and 5 T, which is less than the expected value of 6 NμB for two Co(II) ions, also suggesting the spin-canting state at the low temperature range. Additionally, from the M/NμB vs H/T plot (Figure S16b in the ), it is observed that the isothermal magnetization curves do not superimpose, which indicates anisotropy, so the AC magnetization dynamics were also studied as a function of temperature and frequency, in zero and higher DC fields and 3.5 Oe AC field (Figure S17a-d, ). However, no ac signals were obtained, which is likely due to a small energy barrier or quantum tunneling of magnetization (QTM), and this rules out the possibility of single molecular magnetic (SMM) behavior of complex 7.

elements.content: All reagents and chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification. FT-IR spectra were obtained on a Nicolate MAGANA-IR 750 spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. TGA measurements were carried out with a TA Instruments SDT Q600. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected on a Bruker D8 AVANCE instrument. C, H, and N microanalyses were done with a 2400 Series-II CHN Analyzer. Magnetic measurements were performed using a Quantum Design VSM SQUID magnetometer. The measured values were corrected for the experimentally measured contribution of the sample holder, while the derived susceptibilities were corrected for the diamagnetism of the samples, estimated from Pascal’s tables.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents and chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification. FT-IR spectra were obtained on a Nicolate MAGANA-IR 750 spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. TGA measurements were carried out with a TA Instruments SDT Q600. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected on a Bruker D8 AVANCE instrument. C, H, and N microanalyses were done with a 2400 Series-II CHN Analyzer. Magnetic measurements were performed using a Quantum Design VSM SQUID magnetometer. The measured values were corrected for the experimentally measured contribution of the sample holder, while the derived susceptibilities were corrected for the diamagnetism of the samples, estimated from Pascal's tables.

elements.content: To a mixture of Co­(OAc)2·4H2O (24.908 mg), H2MBP (14.8 mg), and trans-12-CDA (17.21 mg), 2 mL of water and 2 mL of methanol were added. The mixture was heated at 70 °C for 72 h. Upon slow cooling to room temperature, pink colored block-shaped crystals were obtained (52% yield based on H2MBP), which were then filtered and washed with MeOH and dried in air.

Synthesis of [{Co(H2MBP)2(12-CDA)}⋅(CH3OH)]∞ (1)

To a mixture of Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O (24.908 mg), H2MBP (14.8 mg), and trans-12-CDA (17.21 mg), 2 mL of water and 2 mL of methanol were added. The mixture was heated at 70 °C for 72 h. Upon slow cooling to room temperature, pink colored block-shaped crystals were obtained (52% yield based on H2MBP), which were then filtered and washed with MeOH and dried in air.

X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected using Mo Kα (λ = 0.7107 Å) radiation on a BRUKER APEX II diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector. Data collection, data reduction, and structure solution refinement were carried out using APEX II. All the structures 1–7 were solved by direct methods and refined in a routine manner. In all the cases, the non-hydrogen atoms were treated anisotropically except for disordered atoms. Whenever possible, the hydrogen atoms were located on a difference Fourier map and refined. In other cases, the hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed. In the case of compound 7, the disordered water molecules are refined by constraints using the PART command, with a total occupancy of 1. Crystallographic data are summarized in Table , and CIF files for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC). CCDC 1026873–1026879 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for the paper. Copies of the data can be obtained, free of charge on application to the CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge, CB2 1EZ U.K. [Fax: 44 (1233) 336 033. E-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk].

elements.content: In conclusion, seven Co­(II) coordination polymers have been successfully constructed via solvothermal methods and thoroughly characterized by various physicochemical techniques including SXRD. Angular orientation of the N-donor heterocyclic moiety along with the versatile coordination mode of various carboxylate coligands used contributes an important role in the manifestation of various structural topologies ranging from a 1D chain to an unprecedented 3D framework. In addition to interesting structural features, because of the H-bonding backbone of H2MBP, various water clusters are found to be encapsulated inside the resulting frameworks. One of the coordination polymers, namely, 5, is found to exhibit chirality, which was further corroborated by solid-state CD spectra. From the magnetic experiments, we observe some interesting magnetic behaviors for 7 which reveal the canted magnetic behavior arising due to canted orientation of spins between two carboxylate bridged Co­(II) centers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, seven Co(II) coordination polymers have been successfully constructed via solvothermal methods and thoroughly characterized by various physicochemical techniques including SXRD. Angular orientation of the N-donor heterocyclic moiety along with the versatile coordination mode of various carboxylate coligands used contributes an important role in the manifestation of various structural topologies ranging from a 1D chain to an unprecedented 3D framework. In addition to interesting structural features, because of the H-bonding backbone of H2MBP, various water clusters are found to be encapsulated inside the resulting frameworks. One of the coordination polymers, namely, 5, is found to exhibit chirality, which was further corroborated by solid-state CD spectra. From the magnetic experiments, we observe some interesting magnetic behaviors for 7 which reveal the canted magnetic behavior arising due to canted orientation of spins between two carboxylate bridged Co(II) centers.
